prompt:
INDEX PRODUCT PATTERN ANALYSIS

OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

That is the most straightforward extraction from the given keys.

I'll now produce final answer in plain text.</think>We will show that when a key kₙ (with index n) is written in the form

  kₙ = f(n) · n + g(n)

(with 0 ≤ g(n) < n so that f(n) and g(n) are uniquely determined), then for several of the keys one finds a “nice” value for f(n). (In other words, sometimes kₙ is an exact multiple of n so that g(n)=0.) In our list the keys

  k₇ = 76, k₈ = 224, k₉ = 467, k₁₁ = 1155, k₁₂ = 2683

are given and one may show that they can be written as follows:

• For n = 7:
  76 = 10·7 + 6.
  Thus f(7) = 10 (with remainder g(7)=6).

• For n = 8:
  224 = 28·8 + 0.
  So f(8) = 28 (and here g(8)=0, i.e. k₈ is exactly divisible by 8).

• For n = 9:
  467 = 51·9 + 8.
  Thus f(9) = 51 (with remainder g(9)=8).

• For n = 11:
  1155 = 105·11 + 0.
  So f(11) = 105 (again with no “extra” part since k₁₁ is an exact multiple of 11).

• For n = 12:
  2683 = 223·12 + 7.
  Thus f(12) = 223 (with remainder g(12)=7).

So the answers are:

  f(7) = 10, f(8) = 28, f(9) = 51, f(11) = 105, f(12) = 223.

Note:
In many puzzles of this type (sometimes called “key‐number” or “index product” puzzles) one finds that certain keys are defined by a formula like kₙ = f(n)·n + g(n). In our case the values above come directly from writing each key in that form (that is, dividing kₙ by n and taking the quotient as f(n)). (Also note that k₅ was given separately as k₂·k₃ so it does not fit into this linear formula.) 

Thus, our final answer is:

  f(7) = 10, f(8) = 28, f(9) = 51, f(11) = 105, f(12) = 223.
